reviewText: Good psuedo intelligent mystery with a twist. Like one of the Hammer film noir mysterys of the fifties with an American star headlining a British cast the movie was enjoyable. It was nice to see both Gene Nelson and Faith Domergue in atypicale roles. The timeslip gimmick only used as a device was interesting and then discarded. My copy from Sinister Cinema was not a bad transfer from a 16 mm print.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First a word about privately manufactured DVDs--Often, these transfers are of a quality similar to budget box brands. The films themselves are unrestored and rarely pristine yet still watchable (unless there's an inordinate number of repaired breaks). Extras are non-existent and inclusion of artwork or liner notes varies by manufacturer. These niche companies provide a valuable outlet for movies absolutely unavailable anywhere else, plus their prices are often reasonable.SINISTER CINEMA's dub of THE ATOMIC MAN is of better-than-average quality. This mid-50s British programmer was originally called "Timeslip" and was produced by Merton Park Studios. From 1939 to '60 Merton Park issued primarily who-dun-its. Their last seven years of operation were devoted mainly to a BBC show called THE EDGAR WALLACE MYSTERY THEATRE. Merton Park Studios ceased operation in 1967.FILM SYNOPSIS--An American scientist named Dr. Raynor (Arne) is chased, shot in the back then dumped into a river. He's fished out. Photos reveal a strange aura around him. During surgery to remove the slug, the scientist dies for 7.5 seconds but is revived. Under later interrogation it's discovered that the man answers questions several seconds before they're asked-- he's experienced a "timeslip." Also, his body is so irradiated, X-ray film is spoiled by the powerful emissions.From here the story becomes one of industrial espionage. A newspaperman (Nelson) investigates and discovers that Raynor has a double. Or is the hospitalized fellow the double? In quick order, the truth is revealed, as is the requisite villain. There's a fight, shootout and fear that half of London might be incinerated in an atomic blast. All this in barely over an hour!A final note: Running time of SINISTER's edition of "Atomic Man" is listed as 62 mins. The original British release ran 93 and the American theatrical print 76 minutes. In a story so dense with plot there's bound to be a lot of important data missing, if only an hour-long.Related item:Faith Domergue (Jill Rabowski) portrays Dr. Ruth Adams in the sci-fi fave,THIS ISLAND EARTH(1955).Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(5.4) The Atomic Man (UK-1956) - Gene Nelson/Faith Domergue/Peter Arne/Vic Perry/Joseph Tomelty/Leonard Williams/Barry MacKay
Title: N/A

reviewText: In THE ATOMIC MAN, a reporter and his photographer (played by THIS ISLAND EARTH's Faith Demergue!) are out to solve a mystery involving industrial espionage, an imposter, and "enough plutonium to blow up half of London". Eeevil men have replaced a nuclear physicist w/ a double. Now, they're going to cause a melt-down at the atomic lab! Meanwhile, the real scientist has survived the assassination attempt, and, in an intriguing twist, has had his brain somehow altered, causing him to be 7.5 seconds ahead of time (as in: he answers questions before they are asked). This is a little-known 50s sci-fi yarn. Definitely worth a look...

reviewText: This is a good print, scratched with those suddenly flashes from use but with VG contrast ... very watchable.My rating system: Not Viewable, Poor, Fair, Good, Very Good, Excellent it's like I am in the theatre).If this is a film you have searched for and want to watch for any reason buy it. If you want Blu Ray viewing resolution pass it by. It is a great story a mystery first then sci-fi.I am pleased with this purchase.
summary: After all these years a really joy to watch.
